p: IL-6 is a multifunctional cytokine secreted by monocytes, macrophages, T lymphocytes, endothelial cells, and fibroblasts in the early stages of the infectious process. IL-6 stimulates IgA synthesis in lymphoid structures associated with mucous membranes. The effects of IL-6 are synergistic with those of IL-1b, and it is an essential mediator of the acute phase response [ 31]. TNF-α is produced primarily by activated macrophages but, also, by other cells, including adipocytes, B lymphocytes, keratinocytes, fibroblasts, granulocytes, mast cells, monocytes, NK cells, smooth muscle cells, and T cells. IL-6 stimulates inflammation, under the action of variable stimuli, such as allogenic and bacterial cells, immune complexes, LPS, reactive oxygen species, malignant cells, and viral infections. S. hortensis volatile oil upregulated the gene expression for IL-6 and TNF-α, whereas the S. officinalis and A. graveolens volatile oils had no effect on cytokine gene expression ( Figure 2B,D).
